name: Trusted tools
tagline: Setup help for your personal computer with trusted tools and alternatives for corporate applications.
body:
### Trusted Tools.
Which applications out there can you trust. Unfortunately, you commonly have trust any application you are installing that it won't steal your data, tell on your whereabouts or simply do things you didn't intend.

### Trusted OpenSource applications

* Linux [https://github.com/torvalds/linux](https://github.com/torvalds/linux)
    
    Linux operating system kernel.

* Syncthing [http://syncthing.net](http://syncthing.net)
    
    Awesome direct file syncing between computers.

* Seafile [http://seafile.com](http://seafile.com)
    
    Run your own data server to store files.

* OwnCloud [http://owncloud.org](http://owncloud.org)
    
    Run your own cloud server to store anything from files to address books.

* Baikal [http://baikal-server.com](http://baikal-server.com)
    
    Sync your own personal address book and calendars.

* GPGtools [https://gpgtools.org](https://gpgtools.org)
    
    Encrypt anything.

* TextSecure / Signal iOS app [https://github.com/WhisperSystems](https://github.com/WhisperSystems)
    
    Secure and end-to-end encrypted text messaging on Android & iOS

* LaTeX [http://www.latex-project.org](http://www.latex-project.org)
    
    Common toolkit for scientific writing.

* Atom (Text Editor) [https://atom.io](https://atom.io)
    
    Advanced and editable text editor.

* TextMate (Text Editor) [https://github.com/textmate/textmate](https://github.com/textmate/textmate)
    
    Another common text editor.

* LimeText (Text Editor) [http://limetext.org](http://limetext.org)
    
    Sublime text editor clone.

* CodeBOX (Programming IDE) [https://www.codebox.io](https://www.codebox.io)
    
    Coding IDE with remote coding functionality.

* Homebrew (package manager) [http://brew.sh](http://brew.sh)
    
    Missing package manager for Mac OS X that provides great amount of (OpenSource) software.

* Vagrant (Development environment) [https://www.vagrantup.com](https://www.vagrantup.com)
    
    Quickly setup a development environment for your projects.

* Simbody / OpenSim [https://github.com/simbody/simbody](https://github.com/simbody/simbody)
    
    Simulation toolkit build on an open framework [http://opensim.stanford.edu](http://opensim.stanford.edu).

* OpenOffice [http://www.openoffice.org](http://www.openoffice.org)
* Mozilla Firefox / Thunderbird [https://developer.mozilla.org/](https://developer.mozilla.org/)
* Audacity [http://audacity.sourceforge.net](http://audacity.sourceforge.net)
* Handbrake [https://handbrake.fr](https://handbrake.fr)
* Pidgin [http://www.pidgin.im](http://www.pidgin.im)
* Adium [https://adium.im](https://adium.im)
* VLC [http://www.videolan.org/vlc/](http://www.videolan.org/vlc/)
* Miro/VideoConverter [http://www.getmiro.com](http://www.getmiro.com)

### Recommended applications
These are not trusted or simply not fully available or transparent to the user, but recommended as good alternatives.
* Heartbeat [https://ind.ie](https://ind.ie)
* Taiga project management [https://github.com/taigaio](https://github.com/taigaio)
* ProjectLibre [http://www.projectlibre.org](http://www.projectlibre.org)

### Security applications
These are also recommended, but do things not everybody wants to do.

* OSXAuditor [https://github.com/jipegit/OSXAuditor](https://github.com/jipegit/OSXAuditor)
    
    Collects a lot of data under OS X for review.

### Common applications to STAY AWAY from
We've crafted a small limited list of common applications that many people use, but that you probably want to stay away from. These untrusted tools are common proprietary software and probably don't want to do you any harm. However, it is difficult to verify their internals. STAY AWAY from:

* Dropbox
* Box
* Skype
* Bittorrent Sync
* TeamViewer
* WhatsApp
* Microsoft Office
* Microsoft Windows
